p: We cannot discard that other processes could have been involved in the observed changes in the small mammal diversity and abundances. At DNP small mammals play a key role in the trophic chain being the secondary prey of many mammalian carnivores and raptors ( Kufner 1986) after rabbits Oryctolagus cuniculus. In the late 1980s, a greater than 60% decline in the rabbit population at DNP was caused by an outbreak of rabbit hemorrhagic disease ( Delibes-Mateos et al. 2008) and small mammals have gained importance as a food resource for other predators (e.g., for the Iberian lynx, Palomares et al. 1996). Therefore, the observed changes in the DNP small mammal community might have resulted also from top-down control ( Palomares et al. 1995), a hypothesis that we could not test due to lack of suitable data about time-changing predation pressure on these species.
